snippet: The poisonous air quality prompted the government to declare a “red alert,” closing schools, forcing motorists to stay off the road and shutting factories.
abstract: Beijing for first time declares red alert state of environmental emergency, warning residents that toxic air quality could present immediate threat to their health; alert shows extent and seriousness of China's environmental crisis, which has been driven by lax regulations and breakneck economic growth.

byline.contributor: Chris Buckley contributed reporting, and Mia Li contributed research.

lead_paragraph: The poisonous air quality prompted the government to declare a “red alert,” closing schools, forcing motorists to stay off the road and shutting factories.

headline.main: Smog So Thick, Beijing Comes to a Standstill
headline.print_headline: Smog So Thick, Beijing Comes to a Standstill
